learning_outcomes.description: Understand and intervene in conceptual contest over the rule of law.
Understand key episodes of legal contest in the history of the rule of law.
Understand the role of the rule of law in the context of Western societies over time.
Understand and critically evaluate key schools of thought regarding the rule of law.
Appreciate and critically evaluate the relationship between the rule of law and other principles.
Appreciate and critically evaluate the practical legal and political implications of the rule of law.
Demonstrate analytical reasoning and scholarly research skills in applying this knowledge to debates regarding the rule of law.
Demonstrate ability to communicate clearly and persuasively about the rule of law in written and spoken form.

assessments.task_description:
Students will be assessed on their participation in tutorials. Grades are awarded based on the ability to provide convincing interpretations of set primary sources by presenting evidence drawn from the sources. No marks are awarded for general reflections that don't relate to the texts, unless these are specifically asked for in a tutorial. Additionally, no marks are awarded merely for tutorial attendance, but 5 marks will be deducted from the overall participation grade for each tutorial missed without cause.


This assessment task evaluates students’ abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to submit a 2,00-word research essay based on a selected essay question. Further details about this task are available on the course Blackboard site. 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students will be allocated an approximate time to meet with the coordinator (between 24 and 29 May). At the beginning of the oral assessment, the student will be asked a pre-circulated question that will require the student to consider 2 texts in conjunction. The student should speak in answer for 5-6 minutes (an alarm will sound at 5.45). Two follow-up questions will then be asked that will be intended to allow the student to amplify/clarify their answer (answers should be not exceed 2 minutes each). None of the questions will be intended to trick or intimidate, and your grade can only improve through the Q&A (i.e. your speech will set a floor and the final grade will then be higher or the same, not lower). 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to submit a brief written summary of the weekly set texts. This analysis must conform to the model laid out under the ‘Assessment’ tab on Blackboard. There is no summary due in Week 1.

Each summary is graded out of 10 marks, and you must submit a minimum of 10 summaries. If you submit 10, all 10 will count towards your final grade. If you submit more than 10 (of a maximum of 12), your best 10 summaries will count towards your final grade. A 5-mark penalty from the total grade is deducted per summary missing, where the student submits less than 10 summaries.

This assessment task evaluates students’ abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
